brewery.brewery_description:
Burning Sky Brewery was conceived and set up by Mark as a long term project and my last brewery build (hopefully). Tom was onboard from an early stage, helping with trial brews. Paula joined when we had some beer to sell & does the sensible stuff.

Here, nestled at the base of the South Downs in an old Sussex Barn that has been refurbished to a high standard, we can let our imaginations run wild. The landscape and provenance of our location was a major factor in the brewery’s set up.

The crux of the brewery is to brew the beers that excite us, without compromise in terms of ingredient costs and time – that all too often overlooked ingredient in beer. Whether it’s a fresh hoppy pale, or a oak aged beer – they are all considered and cared for beers that we want to drink.

We have started work on an extensive ageing program – not tempted by short cuts, we are far more interested in tradition and the slow-working yeasts that bring complexities and depths of flavour to the beers. It is not envisaged that the full extent of Burning Sky will be apparent for another 2 or 3 years, when these slow beers are ready and we can fully embark on our blending schedule.

Currently we have the ability to be ageing up to 14,500 litres of beer in a mixture of 225 litre oak barriques & 2500 litre oak foudres. The character of each barrel and beer will develop over time leading us on an exciting journey, where the beer guides us and we work with it, learning from it.

beer.beer_description: Brewed with our friend Yvan De Baets from Brasserie De La Senne, this modern Anglo-Belgian pale ale represents both breweries’ love of crisp pale ales. A high proportion of spelt aids the dryness. Hoppy on the nose with an assertively pleasing bitterness. We remain proudly European!

This mixed fermentation farmhouse beer was aged in one of our oak foudres for six months, before further ageing on damsons, blackberries and blackcurrants. These fruits line the hedgerows around the brewery at this time of year, reflecting the seasonality of this beer. Balanced with the acidity of our house yeast culture, this is a delightful beer to have with friends.

items.badge_description: Fresh from the tap is one of the best ways to enjoy a beer. Just try to use a glass and not drink directly from the tap, as tempting as it may be. That's 170 checkins with the serving style of Draft. Try 5 more for Level 35!

While a pint of traditional English ale will always remain a staple, the craft beer scene in England, much like the rest of the world, has continued to grow at a rapid rate! That's 420 different beers from a brewery from England! Try 5 more for Level 85!

beer.beer_description: Arise is brewed with pilsner and wheat malts and backed up with a huge charge of Citra, Centennial and Amarillo hops to give big peach, pine and resinous aromas. A sessionable Pale Ale that’s perfect anytime of the day.

Pale gold in colour, with a crisp malt edge and sharp bitterness. Plateau has been hopped at different stages of the brew, with a big mix of US & NZ hops to satisfy the discerning drinker.

Full in flavour, zesty, refreshing & low in alcohol, this beer will have you returning to the bar for another.

items.badge_description: Looks like you're getting around. You've enjoyed at least 25 different beers!
Ahh, the trusty pale ale; crisp, refreshing, and always a good choice in a bind. That's 5 different Pale Ales or American Pale Wheats. Try 5 more for Level 2.
Had enough tea and biscuits? Head to the pub for a pint! That's at least 25 beers from the UK. Try 5 more for Level 6.

While a pint of traditional English ale will always remain a staple, the craft beer scene in England, much like the rest of the world, has continued to grow at a rapid rate! That's 25 different beers from a brewery from England! Try 5 more for Level 6!

items.checkin_comment: Aroma is full of freshly roasted coffee and a bit of caramel. Tastes malty, roasty, dry, slightly citrusy, bitter finish.

beer.beer_description: Blessed state is a decadent export strength stout. Full of specialty malts for a rich flavour. Cold conditioned for an extended period, the beer was finished with Cacao nibs and a blend of Brazilian and natural coffee beans from local small batch roasters, Tigermoth.

user.bio: Every loaf of bread is a sad story of wheat that didn't get made into beer.

beer.beer_description: European style pale ale with a snappy malt profile and an assured bitterness. Hopped throughout with Celeia, Strisselspalt, Saaz and Centennial for a layered textural quality. Aromas of cut grass, light citrus fruits and a delicate peppery note.

items.badge_description: It's the final week! Week 4 wraps with the last 3 styles of this year's Year in Beer Style Hunt. You've just tried one of three available styles during the week.

beer.beer_description: Monolith was aged for three years in a Chianti foudre with wild yeast strains. The result is full of chocolate and vinous oak flavours, with pleasing farmhouse aromas and mild acidity.

items.checkin_comment: Really nice for a drier strong stout. Loads of coffee and chocolate

beer.beer_description: Blessed state is a decadent export strength stout. Full of specialty malts for a rich flavour. Cold conditioned for an extended period, the beer was finished with Cacao nibs and a blend of Brazilian and natural coffee beans from local small batch roasters, Tigermoth.

items.badge_description: Thanks for staying at home, and checking in with Untappd! It allows us to stay connected to a community of beer lovers, just like you, even if we can't be in the same physical location. From our home to yours, cheers and stay safe!

It's time to give bottle shops some love by adding them as your purchased location. That's 85 check-ins with a purchased location! Tag 5 more to get to Level 18. Want to learn more about this badge? Check out our podcast

There's beer in them thar hills! You're setting off on your journey through the world of beer, but be sure to take a little time to get to know each brewery as you go. That's a beer from 150 different breweries. Try 5 more for Level 31!

While a pint of traditional English ale will always remain a staple, the craft beer scene in England, much like the rest of the world, has continued to grow at a rapid rate! That's 320 different beers from a brewery from England! Try 5 more for Level 65!

beer.beer_description: Blessed state is a decadent export strength stout. Full of specialty malts for a rich flavour. Cold conditioned for an extended period, the beer was finished with Cacao nibs and a blend of Brazilian and natural coffee beans from local small batch roasters, Tigermoth.

items.badge_name: Wake Up and Smell The Coffee! (Level 9)
items.badge_description: Coffee has long been a flavor counterpart for stouts and porters, which means Coffee's not just for breakfast anymore. That's 45 different beers with the style of Porter - Coffee, Porter - Imperial / Double Coffee, Stout - Imperial / Double Coffee, or Stout - Coffee. Try 5 more for Level 10!

beer.beer_description: We hopped this IPA with wonderful Riwaka and Moteuka hops from Hop Revolution in New Zealand. Cheekily paired with Citra for huge stonefruit, citrus and herbal notes, Industry Standard is anything but.

We hopped this IPA with wonderful Riwaka and Moteuka hops from Hop Revolution in New Zealand. Cheekily paired with Citra for huge stonefruit, citrus and herbal notes, Industry Standard is anything but.
Sumptuous malts, apparent but easy going bitterness to allow full flavours of the Nelson Sauvin and Riwaka hop schedule. White grape, gooseberry and passionfruit to the fore!

items.badge_description: Your quest to quench your thirst leaves no stone unturned! That's at least That's 470 distinct venues!
Had enough tea and biscuits? Head to the pub for a pint! That's at least 465 beers from the UK. Try 5 more for Level 94.

beer.beer_description: A bright and clean citrus led IPA with a stealth like malt bill. A triple hit of Citra, Chinook and Columbus hops ensure it’s bang on target

We hopped this IPA with wonderful Riwaka and Moteuka hops from Hop Revolution in New Zealand. Cheekily paired with Citra for huge stonefruit, citrus and herbal notes, Industry Standard is anything but.

Arise is brewed with pilsner and wheat malts and backed up with a huge charge of Citra, Centennial and Amarillo hops to give big peach, pine and resinous aromas. A sessionable Pale Ale that’s perfect anytime of the day.

items.badge_description: Are you crazy? Five different types of beer in one day? Hope you were just sampling.

beer.beer_description: Arise is brewed with pilsner and wheat malts and backed up with a huge charge of Citra, Centennial and Amarillo hops to give big peach, pine and resinous aromas. A sessionable Pale Ale that’s perfect anytime of the day.

Pale gold in colour, with a crisp malt edge and sharp bitterness. Plateau has been hopped at different stages of the brew, with a big mix of US & NZ hops to satisfy the discerning drinker.

Full in flavour, zesty, refreshing & low in alcohol, this beer will have you returning to the bar for another.

Easy Answers is a luscious, clean drinking IPA with good body and subdued bitterness to let the aroma hops shine. Simcoe takes centre stage with Centennial and Chinook. 

Easy Answers will come easy.

This beer has a primary fermentation with a Saison yeast, then undergoes a secondary fermentation with a blend of Lactobacillus & Brettanomyces. The result is tart, crisp, slightly sour & incredibly refreshing.

A satisfying blend of malts to provide a juicy backbone and a pale amber colour. An expansive blend of US hops give a resinous mouthfeel, big citrus and tropical fruit flavours, which are prominent, yet well balanced.
Robust Porter uses the finest Maris Otter barley and a complex range of roast and crystal malts. Hopped with spicy Sussex grown Target hops, this rich and satisfying beer is sure to fortify you.

Pretty Mess is full of juicy, fruity aroma hops. 

Innocent and playful, it crosses boundaries to create an eminently drinkable modern India Pale Ale.

Hops: Citra, Mosaic and Amarillo.

Saison Été was brewed with fresh eldeflowers, picked from the hedgerows around the brewery. After fermentation, it was aged on whole gooseberries. Which combined with our blend of saison and wild yeast strains gives a tart, thirst quenching taste - perfect for the summer.
This mixed-fermentation saison is a light and easy-drinking small beer. Aged in white wine barrels, this delicate beer was then dry-hopped for a refreshing finish.

Good luck in finding this place – a small nook in the South Downs behind the brewery. Our full strength IPA nods to the best I found whilst travelling the US.

The result is deceptively drinkable, with a burnt orange colour and full flavour in the mouth. Huge amounts of Simcoe & Centennial hops find their way into the kettle, with even more sneaking in post fermentation for a ‘proper’ IPA flavour.

We hopped this IPA with wonderful Riwaka and Moteuka hops from Hop Revolution in New Zealand. Cheekily paired with Citra for huge stonefruit, citrus and herbal notes, Industry Standard is anything but.

In a break from our foraged ingredients, this year we are brewing a beer to evoke the feeling of Spring. A time when the dormant plants come to life, when there is freshness and hope in the air after the cold dark winter months.

The beer will be brewed with a dual Saison strain and dry hopped prior to kegging for a clean spritzy celebration of Springtime.

Out of Vogue is a classic West Coast style Pale Ale. Balanced malt body from Maris Otter pale and a small portion of crystal malts. Assertive bitterness with floral and pine resin aromas.

Hops: Cascade, Chinook, Simcoe, Centennial
This black beer was aged for eight months in a Chianti foudre with wild yeast strains. The result is full of chocolate and vinious oak flavours, with pleasing farmhouse aromas and mild acidity.

Choosing our best Saison à la Provision from Foudre no. 1 and from a number of Chardonnay barriques, we then blended in a large portion of Lambic, imported from Belgium that has been aging at Burning Sky.
This crisp modern Saison is loaded with beautiful noble hop varieties for enlightened refreshment and maximum drinkability.
Black ruby in colour, with a rich chocolate and black malt flavour. This old style running porter finishes with a firm bitterness.

A special release of our Saison Provision, this beer was aged on a mix of while yellow and white peaches for three months. Delicious redolent fruit flavours married with our classic house acidity gives us a beer to truly savour.
An autumnal beer that has been fermented on whole local elderberries with our house Saison yeast strain. Pleasing to the eye, with light and crisp Burgundy flavours.

Brewed with our friend Yvan De Baets from Brasserie De La Senne, this modern Anglo-Belgian pale ale represents both breweries’ love of crisp pale ales. A high proportion of spelt aids the dryness. Hoppy on the nose with an assertively pleasing bitterness. We remain proudly European!

Brewed with the same base recipe as all our ‘seasonal saisons’ follow, L’Hiver has been infused with hawthorn leaves and berries to give a most wintery feel to the beer – an almost barren taste (in a good way!) Our use of Brettanomyces and Lactobacillus yeasts ensure this beer continues to develop in flavour.

Saison Anniversaire is a celebration of everything we at Burning Sky love about saisons. Lightly spiced in the boil, this special edition beer was fermented and aged entirely in French Chardonnay barriques using our house saison and a blend of wild yeast strains.

Brewed with Pilsner malt and noble German hop varieties, fermented cold then dry hopped and lagered for an extended period. Flavours of cereal malt combined with citrus and grassy hop aromas, Crisp Finish
This IPA is incredibly dry to let the wine-like Nelson Sauvin hops shine. A high level of carbonation adds to the spritzy refreshing nature.
Ageing in oak vats for many months.  Big vinous aromas meld with oak and dark berries on the nose.  A blend ofspeciality malts create luxuriantly rich and smooth texture of rich chocolate flavours.
